page_analysis.text_content:
Gross vs. net lot area

Gross lot area is the size of the lot—from lot line to lot line. Development potential is based on the net lot area and while gross and net lot area are the same for most lots in Palo Alto, there are some lots for which portions must be excluded from the gross lot area to establish the net lot area.

Areas excluded from the gross lot size are:
• Street right-of-way (Area A of Fig 1 on this page)
• “Pole” portion of a flag lot (Area B of Fig 2 on this page)
• Creek channel (Area C of Fig 3 on this page)

Fig 1 Gross lot area exclusions: street easements

Lot with boundaries that extend into the public ROW

The portion of the lot within the public ROW must be subtracted from the gross lot area.

Note: In some areas of Palo Alto, like Barron Park, it is not unusual for the lot to extend to the middle of the street. However purposes, the lot is defined by the edge of the public street easement or public right-of-way (ROW). Dimensions for the public ROW are available at the Development Center

Fig 2 Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot “poles”

Flag lot accessed via private easement

Flag lot with “pole”

“pole” portion of a lot must be subtracted the gross lot size

Note: Private access easements that provide access to lots are NOT subtracted the lot on which they occur.

Fig 3 Gross lot area exclusions: creek easements

Top of bank

Lot with creek and/or creek easement

The portion of the lot within a creek channel must be subtracted from gross lot size.

Note: The channel or area to be subtracted is defined by Santa Clara Valley Water District’s easement or, if there is no easement, the top-of-bank. Determining the top-of-bank may require a surveyor.

Key

Curb
Sidewalk
Lot lines

Creek
Area that must be subtracted from gross lot area

visual_elements.description: Fig 1 Gross lot area exclusions: street easements. Diagram shows a lot with boundaries extending into the public right-of-way (ROW). The portion of the lot within the public ROW is marked as Area A and must be subtracted from the gross lot area. The diagram includes a street with cars, curb, sidewalk, and public ROW dimension indicated.

Fig 2 Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot 'poles'. Diagram shows two adjacent flag lots: one accessed via private easement and one with a 'pole' portion marked as Area B. The 'pole' portion must be subtracted from the gross lot size. Note clarifies that private access easements providing access to lots are NOT subtracted from the lot on which they occur.

Fig 3 Gross lot area exclusions: creek easements. Diagram shows a lot with a creek and/or creek easement marked as Area C. The portion of the lot within the creek channel must be subtracted from the gross lot size. The top of bank is indicated. Note explains that the channel or area to be subtracted is defined by Santa Clara Valley Water District’s easement or, if none, the top-of-bank, which may require a surveyor.
Key for diagram symbols: Curb, Sidewalk, Lot lines, Creek, and Area that must be subtracted from gross lot area.

technical_specifications.value: Size of the lot—from lot line to lot line
Gross lot area minus excluded portions (street right-of-way, flag lot pole portion, creek channel)
Street right-of-way portion of lot to be excluded
Pole portion of a flag lot to be excluded
Creek channel portion of lot to be excluded

subheadings: Areas excluded from the gross lot size are:
sections: Fig 1 Gross lot area exclusions: street easements
Fig 2 Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot “poles”
Fig 3 Gross lot area exclusions: creek easements

additional_notes: Note under Fig 1 mentions that in some areas like Barron Park, lots may extend to the middle of the street but for purposes of measurement, the lot is defined by the edge of the public street easement or public right-of-way (ROW).
Note under Fig 2 clarifies that private access easements providing access to lots are NOT subtracted from the lot on which they occur.
Note under Fig 3 states that the channel or area to be subtracted is defined by Santa Clara Valley Water District’s easement or, if none, the top-of-bank, which may require a surveyor.
No handwritten annotations, stamps, or markings detected.

qualifiers.text: Development potential is based on the net lot area and while gross and net lot area are the same for most lots in Palo Alto, there are some lots for which portions must be excluded from the gross lot area to establish the net lot area.

In some areas of Palo Alto, like Barron Park, it is not unusual for the lot to extend to the middle of the street. However purposes, the lot is defined by the edge of the public street easement or public right-of-way (ROW).
Private access easements that provide access to lots are NOT subtracted from the lot on which they occur.
The channel or area to be subtracted is defined by Santa Clara Valley Water District’s easement or, if there is no easement, the top-of-bank. Determining the top-of-bank may require a surveyor.

conditions.text: The portion of the lot within the public ROW must be subtracted from the gross lot area.
The 'pole' portion of a flag lot must be subtracted from the gross lot size.
The portion of the lot within a creek channel must be subtracted from gross lot size.

logical_relationships.expression: Net lot area = Gross lot area minus (Area A + Area B + Area C)

execution_sequence.action: Identify and subtract the portion of the lot within the public ROW (Area A) from the gross lot area.
Identify and subtract the 'pole' portion of a flag lot (Area B) from the gross lot area.
Identify and subtract the portion of the lot within a creek channel (Area C) from the gross lot area.
